summary: This issue reports a hydration mismatch error occurring when using dynamic imports with SSR in Next.js. Users are seeing console warnings about server/client HTML mismatches. The issue appears when components render differently between server and client due to browser-specific APIs being called during SSR.
root_cause: The likely root cause is that a component is using browser-specific APIs (like `window` or `localStorage`) during server-side rendering, causing the server HTML to differ from the client-rendered HTML. This creates a hydration mismatch because React expects the initial client render to match the server output exactly.
solution_steps: Identify the component causing the mismatch by checking the console warnings for specific component names
Wrap browser-specific code in useEffect() hook which only runs on the client
Add typeof window !== 'undefined' checks before accessing browser APIs
Use Next.js dynamic imports with { ssr: false } option for client-only components
Test with SSR disabled temporarily to confirm the component is the source of the issue
Consider using the 'use client' directive for components that require browser APIs
checklist: Read and understand the Next.js hydration error documentation
Set up a local Next.js development environment
Reproduce the issue with a minimal example
Identify all browser-specific API usage in the affected components
Implement proper client-side checks using useEffect or dynamic imports
Test the fix with SSR enabled and disabled
Verify no hydration warnings remain in the console
Add a test case to prevent regression
Submit PR with detailed description of the fix
